text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmits a complete revision to IRM 5.5.4, Collecting Actions on Insolvency and Decedent Cases that is being renamed to represent the content matter in which guidance is being provided on. This IRM section has been completely rewritten to provide direction on preparation of proofs of claim, monitoring proofs of claim, compliance with state laws regarding timely filing of proofs of claim and technical guidance related to claim procedures.

Procedures in Decedent Cases

) This section describes Advisory actions in relation to decedent estate ings and is meant to emphasize time sensitive deadlines in state probate proceedings that impact timely case actions to protect the Government’s interest. (
) Use the information in this section to guide you in the filing, processing and monitoring of Proofs of Claim (POC) and decedent files maintenance. (
) Additional resources: (cid:
) Refer to your local law guide for state specific information, located on My SB/SE Counsel web page under the link for law guides, http:// ccintranet.prod.irscounsel.treas.gov/Or
trat/Offices/sbse/Pages/La
uides.aspx. (cid:

, Probate Proceedings (cid:
) IRM

, Legal Reference Guide for Revenue Officers, Insolvencies and Decedents’ Estates, and confer with Area Counsel when confronted with decedent issues beyond your scope of knowledge and expertise. (cid:
) Publication
, Survivors, Executors and Administrators (cid:
) Decedent Estates page, located on MY SB/SE Collection web page: (

) Advisory offices responsible for processing decedent cases and related will draft a local decedent guide for the states they work. This guide must address specific state proceeding time requirements and thresholds that will assist employees in taking timely action to protect the Government’s The guide should address issues such as time periods for filing a proof of claim, period of time to reject a claim, deadlines to institute suit or appeal rejected claims, thresholds on fees, bond requirements, deadlines for filing inventory, etc. Confer with Area Counsel for their input and assistance with terpretation of state law provisions. Review local law guides to determine if these time requirements or thresholds have been addressed and conduct internet research of state probate codes for information to be included in guide. (
) See template for preparation of Decedent Guides in Exhibit

guides will not reiterate procedures that are currently addressed in the decedent IRMs. Instead, the decedent guides should address specific time frames that are mandated for state probate proceedings that have impact timeliness of action that needs to be taken by Advisory. These guides be updated every two years based on probate rulings within that period, modifications should be approved by Counsel. (

) If Area Counsel advises not to file POCs in specific jurisdictions, the opinion must be added to the local decedent guide or local law guide. In a case, the local decedent guide should address actions the office will take protect the Government’s interest in these jurisdictions, see IRM
, Proof of Claim Requirement. (

) Advisory may receive requests for actions such as POC, payoff or release lien from various sources including estate administrators, requests for assis- tance from Counsel or referrals from revenue officers or ACS. Internal Revenue Manual
of Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases 5.5.4
Use the information in this section to guide you in the filing, processing and monitoring of Proofs of Claim (POC) and decedent files maintenance.
Decedent Estates and Estate (
) These requests should be acted on promptly, within the state time frames es- tablished for the action requested. (

) Upon receipt of these requests Advisory will establish decedent case controls on the Integrated Collection System (ICS). Advisory will create an ICS Non- Field Investigation (NFOI) with ICS action code
) When creating an NFOI in the summary screen, under the section titled “Module Dates,” input the due date for any action necessary, the earliest CSED, and the lien refile date. (

) Schedule follow up notifications in ICS at appropriate dates that coincide with time sensitive deadlines established by state probate proceedings to ensure maximum collection and protection of the Government’s interests. (
) Input all cross reference EIN’s (for
returns), SSN’s (for
returns) or any business entity operated by the estate, in the cross reference fields or ICS history. (

) There is no absolute rule when a decedent case should be transferred from the field to Advisory. Every case needs to be evaluated and a determination made based on the facts of each case. This may depend on what action or inaction is being taken to liquidate estate assets to pay creditors of the estate. Factors to be considered in your determination are listed below, also refer to IRM
, Advisory Referrals. (

) If the assets are presently under control of the probate or surrogate’s court (a probate proceeding is usually dependent or supervised), the case should be referred to Advisory to maintain control. (

) If the assets are not under the control of the court and the case is assigned to the field, the revenue officer can continue collection efforts. The revenue must conduct research at the probate court to determine if there is a probate proceeding and the present status of that proceeding (open, closed, assets in litigation, assets pending distribution, etc). The docket sheet outlines what has been filed in a proceeding, it may be available electronically or in the probate file. Obtaining records from probate proceedings is critical to decision making. Advisory should document the ICS history concerning any documentation received concerning payment of creditors or distribution of assets, as this may impact collection actions. (

) If the account is assigned to the field, the revenue officer should determine if a POC has been filed by researching probate records and before contacting the estate administrator or Advisory. If a POC has not been filed and the probate proceeding is open, contact Advisory and request the claim be filed to protect the Government’s interest. It may not be necessary to close the case to Advisory simply to file a POC if collection can continue. (

) If the estate is involved in litigation (concerning assets, lien priority, heirship, etc) or the estate administrator is not taking action to pay creditors, Advisory Counsel should be consulted on how to proceed. Documents concerning the litigation will need to be reviewed and sent with a referral. See IRM
, Referral to Area Counsel for Judicial Action for additional information.
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
(12-06-2011) Field and Advisory Responsibilities
Factors to be considered in your determination are listed below, also refer to IRM
, Advisory Referrals. (

) If the assets are presently under control of the probate or surrogate’s court (a probate proceeding is usually dependent or supervised), the case should be referred to Advisory to maintain control. (

) If the assets are not under the control of the court and the case is assigned to the field, the revenue officer can continue collection efforts. The revenue officer must conduct research at the probate court to determine if there is a probate proceeding and the present status of that proceeding (open, closed, assets in litigation, assets pending distribution, etc). The docket sheet outlines what has been filed in a proceeding, it may be available electronically or in the probate file. Obtaining records from probate proceedings is critical to decision making. Advisory should document the ICS history concerning any documentation received concerning payment of creditors or distribution of assets, as this may impact collection actions. (

) If the account is assigned to the field, the revenue officer should determine if a POC has been filed by researching probate records and before contacting the estate administrator or Advisory. If a POC has not been filed and the probate proceeding is open, contact Advisory and request the claim be filed to protect the Government’s interest. It may not be necessary to close the case to Advisory simply to file a POC if collection can continue. (

) If the estate is involved in litigation (concerning assets, lien priority, heirship, etc) or the estate administrator is not taking action to pay creditors, Advisory or Counsel should be consulted on how to proceed. Documents concerning the litigation will need to be reviewed and sent with a referral. See IRM
, Referral to Area Counsel for Judicial Action for additional information.

If the estate is involved in litigation (concerning assets, lien priority, heirship, etc) or the estate administrator is not taking action to pay creditors, Advisory or Counsel should be consulted on how to proceed. Documents concerning the litigation will need to be reviewed and sent with a referral. See IRM
, Referral to Area Counsel for Judicial Action for additional information.
in Decedent Cases
page (
) If the probate proceeding is closed, the assets distributed, the estate trator did not have knowledge of tax due the case should not be referred to Advisory. See IRM
, Working Decedent Cases, for guidance on case actions in this circumstance. (
) If Advisory files a POC, Advisory is responsible for the following: (cid:
) follow up on acceptance or rejection of the claim (cid:
) reviewing notices related to distribution of estate assets/funds to if the Service is paid the appropriate amount (cid:
) follow up on status of assets and probate proceedings (cid:
) determination if all required tax returns have been filed (cid:
) that distribution is made in accordance with final accounting (cid:
) preparation of a referral to Counsel if required (
) Whether the account is in the field or Advisory, related accounts for entities that were owned by the decedent should be associated to address all tax accounts and POCs can be filed if necessary. (
) Once an NFOI is established Advisory needs to analyze what action is document a plan of action and set follow up dates in ICS. IRM
, Field Collection Actions, provides guidance to assist in your initial analysis ing estate assets. (
) Determine outstanding tax liabilities, cross reference related entities and secure unfiled returns to file accurate POCs or provide notice of tax due to estate administrators. (
) Advisory is responsible for input of TC
and
) IRC Section

(b) suspends the period for collection in any judicial ing when all or substantially all of the assets of a taxpayer are under control of a court. If this condition is present, input Transaction Code (TC)
, Closing Code (CC)
in the case of a probate. See IRM
, tion Statute Expiration Dates, for additional information regarding CSEDs. (

) Advisory is responsible to take action to refile NFTLs on accounts they are monitoring and at the time an NFOI is being closed. Document the ICS as to whether the NFTL was refiled or the reason why it was not. (
) Ensure the NFTL is filed in the proper location based on estate assets (not location of the executor). (
) If the Service is in litigation keep NFOI controls open and set a notification in ICS to refile the lien, so the NFTL does not self release. (

) In all cases being monitored, contact Area Counsel immediately if any document (without limitation: application, motion, notice, objection, petition, etc.) is filed with the Court that seeks to contest, defeat, dispute, disregard misclassify the IRS claim, or that may have that effect. Time is of the in such cases because a notice of removal to the federal district court of any dispute of the merits of a federal tax assessment or lien must be filed within thirty days of receipt by the IRS of the initial pleading raising such an issue. It is essential that such issues be litigated in the federal courts whenever possible.
of Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases 5.5.4 page
If the Service is in litigation keep NFOI controls open and set a notification in ICS to refile the lien, so the NFTL does not self release.

In all cases being monitored, contact Area Counsel immediately if any document (without limitation: application, motion, notice, objection, petition, etc.) is filed with the Court that seeks to contest, defeat, dispute, disregard or misclassify the IRS claim, or that may have that effect. Time is of the essence in such cases because a notice of removal to the federal district court of any dispute of the merits of a federal tax assessment or lien must be filed generally within thirty days of receipt by the IRS of the initial pleading raising such an issue. It is essential that such issues be litigated in the federal courts whenever possible.
Decedent Estates and Estate (

) Advisory will follow up with the court or estate administrator to determine the status of proceedings and secure additional documents related to probate ceedings. Research electronic systems that provide access to docket sheets court records, review correspondence from the court or administrator or make contact with the estate administrator. (
) Advisory will be responsible for actions outlined in IRM

) A proof of claim (POC) is a written statement that sets forth a claim against probate estate of a deceased debtor. To share in distribution from the probate estate most probate courts will not consider payment of a debt unless a claim is submitted. Under state law an estate administrator may be subject to liability for paying creditors who do not file a claim. (
) The Service may file a Form

, Proof of Claim for Internal Revenue with the court or location mandated by state law to give notice of taxes due. filing a POC the Service is notifying the estate administrator of taxes due, putting the Service in a higher priority among other creditors to be paid. (
) Delegation Order Number
establishes authority for Advisory and Insol- vency employees to sign POCs. The signature should be notarized if required by state law or court rules. (
) Prior to the bar date, file the POC for the full assessed tax liability even when other action is pending that may alter the amount. (
) When related taxpayer entities (such as a business) are involved in separate proceedings, prepare a separate POC for each of them. If taxes accrue after the proceeding commences file Form
, Statement of Internal Revenue Taxes Due as an Expense of Administration of an Estate. See IRM
, Providing Notification of Federal Taxes Due. (
) Form

can be generated on ICS, when you are in the case pull up the templates and click on ″Enter Data Grid″. It populates the taxpayer TIN, Address, Advisor information etc. The user will have to enter the Tax Periods since the NFOI does not contain them and can then print the form. (
) Letter

, Proof of Claim Cover Letter, will be sent with the POC. This letter provides information to estate administrators on the Government’s position regarding federal law and its impact on state statutes. A facsimile NFTL generated by ALS (Automatic Lien System) may be included as an at- tachment to the proof of claim to support the Service’s secured status. (

) It is critical that POCs are followed up on timely to ensure they are received and whether the claim is rejected. If an estate representative does not act on presented claim in accordance with deadlines specified in state statutes (usually
days) such failure may constitute rejection of the claim. (
) Typically state statutes set a specific time period, usually
to

days, for claimant to institute suit or appeal rejection of the claim. If appeal action is taken the claim may be barred forever from being paid. If a claim is rejected may be necessary to file a suit in federal district court and Counsel should be consulted as soon as possible to take action before the deadline. (
) Federal courts do have jurisdiction on actions to determine validity, priority amount of claims against a decedent’s estate. Filing suit in federal court is Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
R
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate Tax
Prior to the bar date, file the POC for the full assessed tax liability even other action is pending that may alter the amount.
Federal courts do have jurisdiction on actions to determine validity, priority and amount of claims against a decedent’s estate. Filing suit in federal court is
of Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases 5.5.4
in Decedent Cases
highly recommended in circumstances when the assessment lien or lien has been established prior to death to determine priority of payment of taxes due. (

) If estate assets are under control of the probate court (supervised or dependent administration) enforced collection efforts should not be taken the claim is filed or notice and demand is made without seeking Counsel approval before. (

) Any property which is exempt from a proceeding by statute may be levied upon. Before levy, consult with Counsel to determine that the property is not subject to administration by the court. Amounts not collected in the may be collected from non-probate property. (

) Probate proceedings do not typically have an automatic stay that prohibits lection or filing of a federal tax lien. Attempts to collect are first addressed the estate administrator, if claims or demand for payment are not honored Counsel and/or the local decedent guide should be consulted on next to take. (

) If Area Counsel advises not to file POCs in specific jurisdictions the Counsel opinion must be added to the local decedent guide or local law guide. Notice of taxes due must still be provided to the estate administrator. (

) Filing a POC may subject the claim to action by the court where the ing is conducted. In a probate action, a state court can rule on the merits of claimed federal tax liability. Do not file a POC in jurisdictions where there is history of adverse decisions. (
) In jurisdictions where POCs are not filed, provide notification of amounts to the estate administrator or other fiduciary. Form

, Notice of Federal Taxes Due, must be sent to the estate administrator. A copy of the letter may be filed with the court. This form advises the estate administrator of the owed and of their potential personal liability under
U.S.C. §
The history must be documented indicating the date the Form
was sent putting the estate administrator on notice of tax due. See IRM
, Providing Notification of Federal Taxes Due, for additional guidance. (
) If taxes accrue after the probate proceeding commences send Form

to the estate administrator if this person is responsible for paying the taxes. If a person operating the business is different from the estate administrator and it is unclear whether the person operating the business is a fiduciary appointed by the court, send a Form

to the estate administrator, in addition to the person operating the business. A copy of the form should be filed with the court. Filing a copy of the form with the court makes the judge aware that estate liabilities are increasing and unresolved. See IRM
, Claiming Taxes as an Administrative Expense, for additional guidance. (

) In all cases, contact Area Counsel immediately if any document (without tion: application, motion, notice, objection, petition, etc.) is filed with the that seeks to contest, defeat, dispute, disregard or misclassify the IRS claim, or that may have that effect. Time is of the essence in such cases because notice of removal to the federal district court of any dispute of the merits of a federal tax assessment or lien must be filed within thirty days of receipt by IRS of the initial pleading raising such an issue. It is essential that such be litigated in the federal courts whenever possible. Internal Revenue Manual
highly recommended in circumstances when the assessment lien or recorded lien has been established prior to death to determine priority of payment of taxes due.
5.5.4.6.1 (12-06-2011) No Proof of Claim Requirement
) In jurisdictions where POCs are not filed, provide notification of amounts to the estate administrator or other fiduciary. Form

, Notice of Federal Taxes Due, must be sent to the estate administrator. A copy of the letter may be filed with the court. This form advises the estate administrator of the owed and of their potential personal liability under
U.S.C. §
The history must be documented indicating the date the Form
was sent putting the estate administrator on notice of tax due. See IRM
, Providing Notification of Federal Taxes Due, for additional guidance. (
) If taxes accrue after the probate proceeding commences send Form

to the estate administrator if this person is responsible for paying the taxes. If a person operating the business is different from the estate administrator and is unclear whether the person operating the business is a fiduciary by the court, send a Form

to the estate administrator, in addition to the person operating the business. A copy of the form should be filed with the court. Filing a copy of the form with the court makes the judge aware that estate liabilities are increasing and unresolved. See IRM
, Claiming Taxes as an Administrative Expense, for additional guidance. (

) In all cases, contact Area Counsel immediately if any document (without tion: application, motion, notice, objection, petition, etc.) is filed with the that seeks to contest, defeat, dispute, disregard or misclassify the IRS claim, or that may have that effect. Time is of the essence in such cases because notice of removal to the federal district court of any dispute of the merits of a federal tax assessment or lien must be filed within thirty days of receipt by IRS of the initial pleading raising such an issue. It is essential that such be litigated in the federal courts whenever possible.

In jurisdictions where POCs are not filed, provide notification of amounts to the estate administrator or other fiduciary. Form 10492, Notice of Federal Taxes Due, must be sent to the estate administrator. A copy of the letter may be filed with the court. This form advises the estate administrator of the taxes owed and of their potential personal liability under 31 U.S.C. § 3713. The ICS history must be documented indicating the date the Form 10492 was sent putting the estate administrator on notice of tax due. See IRM 5.5.2.3, Providing Notification of Federal Taxes Due, for additional guidance.
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
Decedent Estates and Estate (

) U.S. territories generally model their revenue laws on the Internal Revenue Code (“I.R.C.”). For guidance concerning laws in U.S. Territories read the in U.S. law guide on the SBSE Counsel website http:// ccintranet.prod.irscounsel.treas.gov/Or
trat/Offices/sbse/Pages/La
uides.aspx. (

) The bar date (court deadline) for filing a POC is time sensitive. The deadline file a creditor claim is mandated by state law. Many state probate codes will Bar Date indicate that creditor claims not filed timely will be barred from payment or that a debt cannot be considered for payment unless a claim is filed. state probate codes or your local law guide to determine the established deadline to file a timely claim to be considered for payment. (

) Comply with the bar date when possible although the Service is not bound state statutes of limitations in the collection of taxes, though state probate ceedings will continue based on deadlines specified by state law. Once filed the claims will be evaluated and decisions made to pay creditors based on those timely filed claims. Therefore it is critical that claims made on behalf the Service be filed timely. If claims are not filed timely, the Service may to litigate to establish its priority. It is of no benefit to the Service to submit a claim for payment after claims have been paid and estate assets have been distributed. (
) Timely filed claims may avoid additional litigation to pursue assets after bution. (

) It is not in the state court’s interest to prolong probate proceedings longer necessary. That is why there are mandated deadlines to keep necessary actions occurring to resolve estate matters and close the proceedings. (
) If the claim filing period has expired, secure probate records to determine status of estate assets (available or distributed). Dates (
) If the bar date has passed and estate assets have not been distributed or involved in litigation file the POC with the proper authority. (

) If the bar date has passed and estate assets have been distributed and the estate is closed do not file the POC. At this point it is best to contact the administrator and request documentation concerning distribution of estate assets to consider transferee issues. In such case determine if the estate ministrator had knowledge of taxes due. (

) In decedent estate proceedings, claim interest to the anticipated date of payment. Typically that date would be after the filing and rejection period and deadlines. Some states may dictate a time period when claims must be presented to the court for approval, that date may also be used. (
) Claim all applicable penalties to the expected payment date. State statutes limiting penalties do not bind the Service. (
) The advisor can calculate the tax, penalty and interest for the claim using IDRS command codes INTST or COMPA. Refer to IRM
, Command Codes INTST, ICOMP and COMPA. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
R
(12-06-2011) Claiming Penalty and Interest
in Decedent Cases

) Command code INTSTB shows the tax, the assessed failure to pay (FTP), assessed interest, assessed penalties other than FTP; these amounts comprise the ″Assessed Total.″ INTSTB also reflects the accrued interest, accrued FTP and total accruals. Finally, it gives the total FTP (assessed and accrued), and the total interest (assessed and accrued) for a ″Total Balance Due″ (assessed total and accrued total). (
) Claim interest and penalties on tax liabilities incurred related to the tion of the estate. (

) An estimated (or unassessed) claim is a POC that is filed when the exact amount owed is still unknown. This may be necessary when the of a tax return is not completed or a tax return has not been filed. An estimated POC protects the Government’s interest before the exact liability determined. (
) One Form
can include both assessed and estimated amounts, identify the estimated portion as “Estimated Liability” in the “Remarks” column. the amount due for each tax period separately. (
) File an amended or supplemental POC as soon possible when the correct liability is determined, once returns are filed or Examination determines the amount of a tax liability or tax deficiency. (
) If no return information is available for a period from which to compute an estimate, annotate “Not Filed” next to the period, and put $
in the tax column. (

) The estimated claim should be based on as much internal information as possible. If the evidence indicates the probability of a refund or no tax due situation exists do not add an estimate to the claim. (
) The following resources may be used to determine an estimated tax liability: (cid:
) IDRS data using command codes such as IRPTR, SUPOL, PMFOL, RTVUE, and BRTVU (cid:
) last return filed information (command code TRDBV) (cid:
) income and expense schedules (cid:
) inventory and appraisement (which may include assets that may not be IRPTR such as pension or retirement accounts, stock accounts and (cid:
) information available from revenue officer’s case file (cid:
) examination files or information from exam functions (proposed notice of deficiency or statutory notice) (cid:
) under reporter information (cid:
) information from the estate administrator (
) If estimated liabilities are listed for unfiled returns, penalties and/or interest not have to be computed. (
) Taxes subject to deficiency procedures remain estimates even if the disagrees with the proposed assessment or fails to respond within the
period because the Service must then issue a statutory notice of deficiency before assessment.
of Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases 5.5.4 page

Command code INTSTB shows the tax, the assessed failure to pay (FTP), assessed interest, assessed penalties other than FTP; these amounts comprise the ″Assessed Total.″ INTSTB also reflects the accrued interest, accrued FTP and total accruals. Finally, it gives the total FTP (assessed and accrued), and the total interest (assessed and accrued) for a ″Total Balance Due″ (assessed total and accrued total).
5.5 Decedent Estates and Estate
Decedent Estates and Estate (

) If a POC has been filed and situations warrant, an amended claim may be as necessary to claim the correct liability owed the Service. Amended Supplemental, for additional tax due should be filed if the probate proceeding is open and: Consolidated (cid:
) additional returns are filed (cid:
) examinations are completed (cid:
) additional liabilities are determined (for example Trust Fund Recovery Penalty) (
) After the bar date, file an “amended” POC to change the amount in a filed claim. Mark the front of the Form
as follows: Amendment No. __ to Proof of Claim dated ________. Avoid filing repeated amendments possible. (
) File a “supplemental” POC when an additional liability is discovered after original claim was filed. Mark the from of Form
as follows: No. __ to Proof Of Claim dated _______. (

) File a “consolidated” POC when two “amended” or “supplemental” have been filed and another change is needed unless the statement of owed is extremely long and complex. “This claim consolidates Proofs of Claim dated _____ and ______.” (
) Mail or hand deliver (if a fee is required) parts one and two of the POC to court official if designated by state law or to the responsible estate and Distribution tor when appropriate. Form
provides distribution directions. A facsimile of Claim NFTL generated by ALS (Automatic Lien System) may be included as an tachment to the proof of claim to support the Service’s secured status. (
) Letter

, Proof of Claim Cover Letter, will be sent with the POC. This letter provides information to estate administrators on acknowledging the the Government’s position regarding federal lien law and its impact on state statutes. (
) The court official will acknowledge receipt by stamping the time and place received on part
Estate administrators should include an letter when returning part
) Retain acknowledgment copy and part
file copy with the Advisory case (
) Furnish part three to the estate administrator, or Court if part
is sent to administrator. (
) Provide part four to the U.S. Attorney, unless that office previously advised Area Director that they prefer not to receive a copy. (
) If an acknowledged POC part
is not received from the court or the within
days, take the following actions to secure one.
check the docket sheet to see if receipt of the claim was acknowledged the probate proceeding records
contact the court or estate administrator and request the acknowledge- ment copy
if still no acknowledgement send a duplicate Form
and Letter to the court or the estate administrator by certified mail.
check the docket sheet to see if receipt of the claim was acknowledged the probate proceeding records
contact the court or estate administrator and request the acknowledge- ment copy
if still no acknowledgement send a duplicate Form
and Letter
to the court or the estate administrator by certified mail.
still no acknowledgement send a duplicate Form 4490 and Letter 4653 the court or the estate administrator by certified mail.
Procedures in Decedent Cases
page (

) On controlled cases Advisory will follow up with the court or estate tor to determine the status of the POC, proceedings and/or estate assets. Research electronic systems that provide access to docket sheets or court records, review correspondence from the court or administrator or make contact with the estate administrator. Advisory should document the ICS concerning any documentation they receive concerning payment of creditors distribution of assets. (

) Each state has specific time frames to consider and reject or approve claims. Advisory needs to input follow up dates on ICS to coincide with these deadlines. Generally the estate administrator will send a notice to the party who submitted the claim to notify them if they will be paid in full, a partial payment or nothing. (

) When the estate administrator or court decides who gets paid a notice of bution (or proposed notice of distribution) of estate assets is sent advising what claims get paid and how much. It must be reviewed in the stated time period to ensure the Service is paid in proper priority and in the appropriate amount. IRM
, Probate Proceedings, provides guidance on expenses. (
) There is a set time period (generally

days, check state law) to appeal this decision (or proposal) and it is critical that this time period is monitored because the Service can lose its appeals rights, which may result in litigation in federal court. (
) On occasion there may be a hearing to dispute priority of creditors. If the Service’s priority is in question, a referral to Area Counsel is necessary . (
) Once distribution is made (received) if there is still tax due a determination needs to be made if there are non-probate assets to collect from or if the should be closed. (

) Follow up dates in ICS should coincide with state time frames for filing a deadlines for response to proposed distribution plan, deadlines to appeal rejection of a claim, etc. A follow up date may be based on anticipated sale date of a property in which payment from the sale proceeds will be applied to outstanding taxes. Follow ups in ICS will help the advisor protect the Govern- ment’s interest and move the case to resolution in a timely manner. (

) If it appears that the executor is not taking appropriate action to pay the creditors of the estate it may be necessary to consult Area Counsel for direction or assistance to resolve a stagnant case. See IRM
for addi- tional information concerning referrals to Counsel. (
) If taxes accrue after the probate proceeding commences send Form

, Statement of Internal Revenue Taxes Due as an Expense of Administration of an Estate, to the estate administrator if this person is responsible for paying the taxes. If a person operating the business is different from the estate istrator and it is unclear whether the person operating the business is a fiduciary appointed by the court, send a Form

to the estate in addition to the person operating the business. A copy of the letter should filed with the court. Filing a copy of the letter with the court makes the judge aware that estate liabilities are increasing and unresolved. See IRM
, Claiming Taxes as an Administrative Expense, for additional guidance. Internal Revenue Manual
of Claim Procedures in Decedent Cases 5.5.4
Decedent Estates and Estate (
) Apply payments as directed when a court order specifies how amounts be credited. (

) Otherwise, apply payments in this order: a. Accounts where the statutory period is about to expire, then the next oldest period b. Trust fund portion of accounts, only when the statutory period for of the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) has expired without ment of the TFRP. c. Decedent guides will not reiterate procedures that are currently addressed in the decedent IRMs. Instead, the decedent guides should address specific time frames that are mandated for state probate proceedings that impact on timeliness of action that needs to be taken by Advisory, such as:
on timeliness of action that needs to be taken by Advisory, such as: (cid:

) What is the period for opening a probate proceeding and appointing an estate administrator? (this is indication of when the probate proceeding should be initiated when a TP dies while the account is in active inventory being worked by an RO) (cid:
) What is the time period to provide an inventory and appraisement to the court? (this is an indication when an employee should follow up on the probate proceedings to determine estate assets) (cid:
) Is there a provision for supervised (dependent or formal) and unsupervised (independent or informal) probate proceedings? (TC
should be input on proceedings in which the estate assets are under control of the court) (cid:
) Are estate assets (real or personal) considered under control of the probate court jurisdiction? (need determine if the CSED is extended in accordance with IRC
) (cid:
) Does the state require a bond for certain types of administration? What are bond amounts set on - value of the gross estate or a percentage of the estate? (cid:
) Does this specific state charge filing fees for claims? (need to make payment arrangements, such as sending OI to RO to file claim with court – if claim cannot be filed with administrator) (cid:
) What is the time period to file a timely POC? (need to know this time period in order for the Service’s claim to be considered for payment) (cid:
) What is the proper venue for filing the POC, with the court or with the estate administrator? (cid:

) Does the state require POCs to be notarized or is a seal (Seal of Office of the Internal Revenue Service and Certification to the Authenticity of Official Documents) adequate to certify taxes due? (cid:
) Does state law prohibit fiduciary from paying claims not presented for payment? (cid:
) What is the time period for the estate administrator to consider creditor claims and/or reject claims? (this provides an indication of when the employee should follow up on the filed POC) (cid:

) What is the time period to appeal a rejected claim? (this is critical to know so that an appeal can be submitted or pull the case into federal district court – depending on the reason for denial) (cid:

) What is the period to object to a motion to disburse estate funds? (need to know time period in the employee must review the distribution list and decide it is satisfactory or take action to disagree) (cid:

) Are there state law provisions that dictate thresholds for reasonable expenses, family allowances, homestead allowances, funeral expenses etc.? (need this information to determine if only reasonable expenses have been paid and if the distribution amount to the IRS is correct or in consideration of discharges (cid:

) Is the estate liable for funeral expenses if the decedent had a funeral or burial policy or contract to costs associated with final disposition? (this is necessary to determine disallowance of funeral (cid:
) Is there a provision for necessity of administration if the estate assets are less than the specific value? (this will assist with decision making regarding filing of a POC) (cid:
) Are there guidelines on priority of payment for insolvent estates? (necessary to determine if our interest is considered appropriately) (cid:

) Does the liability of the estate administrator terminate with the final settlement of the estate or until the administrator has any duties to perform as in their capacity as representative? (When does fiduciary liability expire? Impacts assertion of
fiduciary liability) (cid:
) Is a final order issued by a probate court appealable to the court of appeals? If so within what time period? (cid:
) Does the filing of a proof of claim toll or extend the CSED for this specific state?
